body: @zoewangg I am not aware of anything and did not detect any regressions in our microbenchmarks. Can you share the benchmark / flamegraphs ?

Looking into https://netty.io/news/2019/06/28/4-1-37-Final.html I can't see stuff that could cause any perf hit @zoewangg there is anything on that list that recall you what you're doing in your JMH bench?

This is our benchmark code: https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-java-v2/tree/master/test/sdk-benchmarks/src/main/java/software/amazon/awssdk/benchmark/apicall/httpclient/async

Background: AWS Java SDK v2 uses Netty client under the hood for async requests.  All the benchmark code does is to use netty http client to send sequential or concurrent requests to local mock h1 or h2 servers with openssl or default jdk ssl handler and measure throughput.

Below is the comparison between using 4.1.39 and 4.1.33. There are no SDK changes between the two. Diff <= 100 is treated as tolerable margin.

Benchmark  |  4.1.39 vs. 4.1.33 throughput comparison |     
-----------| --------                          
NettyClientH1NonTlsBenchmark.concurrentApiCall  |  -2.9%
NettyClientH1NonTlsBenchmark.sequentialApiCall |  tolerable difference
NettyHttpClientH1Benchmark.concurrentApiCall (jdk) |  -7.8%
NettyHttpClientH1Benchmark.concurrentApiCall (openssl) | -5%
NettyHttpClientH1Benchmark.sequentialApiCall (jdk) |  tolerable difference
NettyHttpClientH1Benchmark.sequentialApiCall (openssl) |  tolerable difference
NettyHttpClientH2Benchmark.concurrentApiCall (jdk) | -9.8%
NettyHttpClientH2Benchmark.concurrentApiCall (openssl) | -11.4%
NettyHttpClientH2Benchmark.sequentialApiCall (jdk) | tolerable difference
NettyHttpClientH2Benchmark.sequentialApiCall (openssl) | tolerable difference

Looking at the release notes, could this contribute to the slow down? https://github.com/netty/netty/pull/9240/files#r293832922
@zoewangg I don't think so... can you please also share flamegraps ?
Sorry for the delay, we were able to identify the cause for the slowdown. Will report back the issue and possible fix.

Thanks a lot! Looking forward to more details :)

> Am 03.09.2019 um 20:44 schrieb Zoe Wang <notifications@github.com>:
> 
> ﻿
> Sorry for the delay, we were able to identify the cause for the slowdown. Will report back the issue and possible fix.
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you commented.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.

Hi @normanmaurer, after some profiling, it seems this is the change that is affecting us: https://github.com/netty/netty/commit/f17bfd0f64189d91302fbdd15103788bf9eabaa2. Spefically, it seems to be the change to stop using a static instance of `CancellationException` in `DefaultPromise#cancel()` that's taking up extra CPU in our case.

For context, in the SDK we use a new `WriteTimeoutHandler` that is added to the channel pipeline before sending an HTTP request: https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-java-v2/blob/79a22b071b381ecbce2b94ce7935ed879971f25f/http-clients/netty-nio-client/src/main/java/software/amazon/awssdk/http/nio/netty/internal/NettyRequestExecutor.java#L187-L194. Since this handler `cancel`s the pending task on a successful write (which is pretty much 100% in our benchmark code), a lot of time gets taken up creating the exceptions.

Added an SS of the flame graph for a profiling capture I did.
![netty-4-1-39-cancellationexception](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/261310/64210791-07d01780-ce59-11e9-9994-11384670c461.png)

issue.title: Avoid CancellationException construction in DefaultPromise

repository.name: netty
repository.description: Netty project - an event-driven asynchronous network application framework

issue.body:
Motivation

#9152 reverted some static exception reuse optimizations due to the problem with `Throwable#addSuppressed()` raised in #9151. This introduced a performance issue when promises are cancelled at a high frequency due to the construction cost of `CancellationException` at the time that `DefaultPromise#cancel()` is called.

Modifications

- Reinstate the prior static `CANCELLATION_CAUSE_HOLDER` but use it just as a sentinel to indicate cancellation, constructing a new `CancellationException` only if/when one needs to be explicitly returned/thrown
- Subclass `CancellationException`, overriding `fillInStackTrace()` to minimize the construction cost in these cases

Result

Promises are much cheaper to cancel. Fixes #9522.

issue.title: using No StackTrace subclass of CancellationException and ClosedChannelException for improve the performance and less gc

repository.name: netty
repository.description: Netty project - an event-driven asynchronous network application framework

issue.body:
By jmh, noStackTrace faster over 90X, and singleton way faster over 300X
ref: https://github.com/qxo/Common-JMH-benchmark/blob/master/src/main/java/test/ExceptionPerformanceBenchmark.java
```
REMEMBER: The numbers below are just data. To gain reusable insights, you need to follow up on
why the numbers are the way they are. Use profilers (see -prof, -lprof), design factorial
experiments, perform baseline and negative tests that provide experimental control, make sure
the benchmarking environment is safe on JVM/OS/HW level, ask for reviews from the domain experts.
Do not assume the numbers tell you what you want them to tell.

Benchmark                                    Mode  Cnt     Score    Error   Units  Score/min
ExceptionPerformanceBenchmark.baseline      thrpt   10     3.842 ±  0.036  ops/us      1.000
ExceptionPerformanceBenchmark.noStackTrace  thrpt   10   336.346 ±  0.692  ops/us     87.542
ExceptionPerformanceBenchmark.singleton     thrpt   10  1327.454 ± 97.471  ops/us    345.502

```

Motivation:
   jmc profiler with ab  `-n 10000 -c 400 $url ` test on vertx web app 
  found there create lots CancellationException and ClosedChannelException
  
Modification:
   Since these exception used for control flow, StackTrace is useless
   so we can override its fillInStackTrace method and Cache the exception 
   to improve the performance and less gc

Result:
   1. cache control flow exception if it's cloud
   2. override its fillInStackTrace method
   finally to  improve the performance and less gc

body: @dagnir thanks a lot for the details... This makes a lot of sense. @njhill is working on a fix already :)
